Award.AwardTitle: NRT: Training Next-Generation Scientists with Experimental, Theoretical, and Computational Competencies for Complex Interfaces (INTERFACE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award prepares Ph.D. students at the University of Southern Mississippi with the competencies to address grand materials challenges of 21st Century ranging from pharmaceuticals to energy. This traineeship will provide students with interdisciplinary skills needed in industrial, academic, and national laboratories to drive American competitiveness in advanced materials innovation. The program transcends the divide that currently exists across experimental, theoretical, and computational scientists to train a new cadre of scientists and engineers capable of leading the data-driven design of materials in biolubrication, biomaterials, and renewable energy. Through internships and training opportunities, trainees will develop exceptional content knowledge and scientific skills, with honed professional skills, with readiness to communicate science with a wide audience, including K-12 students. This traineeship also seeks to increase the participation and retention of women and underrepresented minorities in doctoral programs by strong linkages with effective programs and organizations.

The central research theme of this NRT program is complex interfaces of polymeric materials. Faculty from polymer science and engineering, chemistry and biochemistry, and physics, as well as staff scientists from national labs and industrial partners, will co-advise trainees in a multidisciplinary team environment. Trainees will engage in both computational and experimental research projects related to bioinspired interfaces, biomaterials interfaces, and charge transport at interfaces. The education program is designed to provide trainees with hands-on access and training in computational and experimental research tools, to encourage critical analysis of the state of literature, and to identify unmet research challenges. Trainees will also receive extensive training in professional skills such as project management, problem solving, conflict resolution, high performance teams, business etiquette, research ethics, and oral and written communication via a series of professional development workshops. As a final element, trainees will participate in internship opportunities designed for exposure to multiple career paths in academia, industry, national labs, and government policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aligned with the Materials Genome Initiative, the NRT INTERFACE program was established with a goal of producing a next-generation STEM workforce trained to function effectively at the boundary of computational and experimental methodologies aimed at addressing grand challenges in soft materials INTERFACEs. An integrated research, education, and professional development platform was designed to broadly prepare trainees for diverse career paths, including academic and non-academic STEM careers. Over the duration of the program, INTERFACE successfully trained 59 graduate students and engaged 20 faculty from disciplines including polymer science and engineering, chemistry and biochemistry, physics, and computational science and informatics, and computer science and engineering. The aggregated demographics for INTERFACE trainees across six cohorts was 39% women (compared with the 5-year average of 32% across the pertinent disciplines at USM) and 11% underrepresented groups (including Black/African American, Hispanic, and Pacific Islander, compared with the 5-year average of 9.8% across the pertinent disciplines at USM). Although accomplished at the end of the current NRT award, the University of Southern Mississippi recently established and hired a Chief Diversity Officer (CDO). The CDO is charged with developing an initial infrastructure for a new Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion and with identifying initial priorities to craft a diversity strategic plan that will advance the university?s efforts to advance diversity across all divisions of the university.

Central elements of the INTERFACE education program included an integrated curriculum designed to provide trainees with hands-on access and training in computational and experimental research tools, computational tutorials taught by external leaders in the field. Based on trainee feedback, the computational tutorials were more effective than semester long courses in broadening exposure to computational methods.  Trainees also received extensive training in professional skills such as 1) project management 2) problem solving, 3) conflict resolution, 4) high performance teams, 5) business etiquette, 6) research ethics, and 7) oral and written communication. The traineeship commenced with a week-long offsite bootcamp designed to introduce trainees to the strategies and tools that allow professionals to work successfully in teams to drive synergistic results, achieve goals, manage multiple priorities, and meet personal expectations. Each day focused on a specific theme and included short lectures, interactive activities, individual reflection, and assignments to build capabilities. As outcomes from bootcamp, trainees were provided with tools to 1) define their individual strengths, 2) define their individual personality and communication styles, 3) build goal-definition, project planning, and time management skills, 4) understand team dynamics, conflict resolution, and negotiation strategies, 5) communicate effectively to different audiences, and 6) promote their ideas and research. Trainees consistently reported skills acquired during bootcamp as foundational components of the INTEFACE program. Oral communication skills training was followed up by completion of the Communicating Science Workshop led by the USM Speaking Center (an institution-wide resource) and engagement in K-12 outreach activities. The INTERFACE Seed Grant Program provided graduate students professional development opportunities to experience grant writing and peer review, to implement project management processes, and to effectively implement communication skills necessary to engage in interdisciplinary research. For many graduate students, the seed program was their first opportunity to develop a real proposal budget. More importantly, the seed program provided the first opportunity for students to manage expenditures and prioritize purchases necessary to achieve the proposed project objectives. In addition to the 59 NRT trainees, the aforementioned program elements impacted the education, training, and development of 287 graduate students who were not NRT trainees.

The NRT Career Experiences program element provided opportunities for trainees to establish connections and collaborations with researchers and mentors from various career paths, including academia, industry, and government lab. Trainees completing an industrial internship experienced key differences in basic research that occurs as part of the PhD and market-driven product development and manufacturing that occurs within industry. Trainees completing an academic internship experienced differences in departmental and lab culture and mentorship styles (in addition to acquiring new scientific skill sets).  Trainees completing a national lab internship experienced the unique mission of the specific lab. Combining any of these internships with an international location provided the trainees with opportunities to experience different research cultures, languages, and general standard operating protocols. While the travel and host-guest restrictions during the COVID-19 pandemic impacted this program element, 24 trainees successfully completed an internship with a distribution of 42% government lab, 37% academia, and 21% industry. In these endeavors, the INTERFACE program worked with more than 15 partner organizations.

Over 6 years, INTERFACE trainees published 65 peer-reviewed paper in high-impact journals such as Science Advances, Nature Communications, Advanced Functional Materials, and ACS Applied Materials and INTERFACEs. Within the same timeframe, INTERFACE faculty and trainees delivered 195 presentations at local, regional, national, and international conferences.
